Award.AbstractNarration:
Random geometric graphs can be used to model many large scale networks, such as the Internet and social networks. Such graphs are particularly suited to the modeling of large-scale sensor and transceiver networks, which are becoming more common as electronic devices become smaller and cheaper and are interconnected in very large networks. Modeling the behavior of these networks is becoming more and more important, and the analysis of the behavior of these networks when they become extremely large is becoming increasingly relevant in practical applications. This award supports research on the properties of these large-scale networks, as well as training of graduate students and early-career researchers in the mathematics of random graphs.

The study of random geometric graphs originated with questions about the way fluids seep through porous media. More recently, the study of large-scale electronic and communication networks has prompted many questions about random geometric graphs. The basic model of random geometric graphs was proposed by Gilbert over fifty years ago: take points randomly in the plane according to a Poisson point process of unit intensity, and join two whenever they are within a prescribed distance of each other. The central question concerning this model is: for what values of the prescribed distance do we obtain an infinite connected component? Surprisingly, even after fifty years, only rough upper and lower bounds are known for the critical value of the prescribed distance. Some properties of this Gilbert model are known, but many other questions still remain unanswered. This research project addresses some of these questions, as well as other questions about related models of random graph inspired by both percolation theory and large-scale communication networks.

POR.DRECONTENT:
During the three year period of this grant the PIs published 24 papers in high-class journals, including one in the most prestigious general math journal, Annals of Mathematics. Most of these papers were in extremal and probabilistic combinatorics, but some were in pure and applied probability theory, number theory, and the confluence of number theory and computer science. In addition to publishing results, they have also disseminated them by giving lectures at universities around the world, like Tel Aviv, Moscow, Cambridge, and Budapest.

 Although the PIs work in pure mathematics, some of their results have important applications outside mathematics. For example, coalescence processes, also known as aggregation, coagulation and gelation, are fundamental to the study of a number of problems in biology, statistical physics, and mathematics. In such a process, some abstract set of domains are iteratively combined, and the evolution of the population of domains is of key interest. Various coalescence models (with different rules governing the rate at which domains combine) have been studied in genetics, cosmology, and much of physical chemistry, with the primary features of interest being the times at which giant domains emerge. They have proved the first results about one of the simplest models, linear coalescence, and shown a number of surprising phenomenon that even linear coalescence exhibits.

Without any doubt, the most significant result of the PIs of the three-year period of this grant is their paper about `making squares': this is closely related to algorithms factoring large integers, which is of great significance in cryptography. Many of the fastest known algorithms for factoring large integers, and hence breaking many commonly used cryptographic algorithms, rely on finding subsequences of randomly generated sequences of integers whose product is a perfect square.

 A useful heuristic, suggested already in the 1970s is to imagine that these integers are chosen uniformly at random in some range. Motivated by this idea, Pomerance posed in 1994 the problem of determining the average threshold, or number of integers we need, before we obtain a product that is a perfect square, as this is closely related to the average running time of the corresponding factoring algorithms, and hence the average time taken to break cryptographic codes. After important results of Pomerance and Croot, Granville, Pemantle and Tetali, giving good bounds on this threshold, a fairly precise conjecture was stated by these authors as to the value of this threshold. In their over 90 page long Annals paper the PIs proved this conjecture.

In addition, the PIs have tackled problems in the theory of monotone cellular automata, modeling the spread of epidemics. Here the most significant achievement is the exact threshold for the so-called Duarte model. The main difficulty with this model is its lack of symmetry: although it is a prominent model, before the PIs exact results, the best result was proved by Mountford in 1995, giving only the order of the threshold. This exact result for the Duarte model requires a refined analysis and a number of new ideas, describing biased growth from a new kind of critical droplets, as compared to symmetric models.

 About 30 university and professional conference talks have been given by the PIs over the course of this award at notable institutions including IMPA in Brazil; Fudan University in Shanghai, China; IMT in Lucca, Italy; University of Cambridge, UK; and MFI in Oberwolfach, Germany. In addition to giving talks to professional mathematicians, the PIs also gave talks to undergraduates and graduates including the Cantor Sect at the University of Memphis, the Archimedeans at the University of Cambridge, UK, and the Budapest Semesters in Mathematics. PI Bollobas gave the 28th Annual Marden lecture a broad, general, multidisciplinary audience at the University of Wisconsin-Milwaukee, one of the main lectures at the large Building Bridges conference in Budapest, and a main lecture in the Asymptotic Geometric Analysis in Tel Aviv. Bollobas also organized an important international conferences, including the Tutte Centenary Conference in Cambridge.

The PIs research activity greatly helped in the training of Ph.D. students, preparing them for careers in research, education, and industry. In addition, regular student seminars have been organized by the PIs in which students present recent results in the field to other graduate students and the PIs.

During the period of this grant, four graduate students were awarded their Ph.D. degrees:

  • Julian D. Sahasrabudhe. Extremal and Ramsey Problems on Graphs and the Integers. (2017). University of Memphis.
  • Amy Shaw. Games on Grids and Graphs. (2017). University of Memphis.
  • Kamil K. Popielarz. Problems in Extremal Graph Theory. (2018). University of Memphis.
  • Stephen G.Z. Smith. Problems in graph theory and partially ordered sets. (2019). University of Memphis.
